required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Open-Label, Randomized Study Evaluating the Absorption and Systemic Pharmacokinetics of Topically Applied IDP-126 Gel in Comparison With Control Gel
clinical_study.official_title: A Phase 1b Open-Label, Randomized Study Evaluating the Absorption and Systemic Pharmacokinetics of Topically Applied IDP-126 Gel in Comparison With Control Gel in Subjects With Acne Vulgaris Under Maximal Use Conditions

brief_summary.textblock: This will be an open-label study designed to assess the safety and plasma PK of topically applied IDP-126 Gel compared to Control Gel.

detailed_description.textblock: To evaluate the safety and plasma pharmacokinetics (PK) of clindamycin and adapalene in IDP-126 Gel compared with that from Control Gel in subjects with moderate to severe acne vulgaris (acne) during once daily topical application of IDP-126 Gel for 28 days.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: Approximately 48 subjects who meet the study criteria will be enrolled and will receive treatment with one of the 2 study drugs. Approximately 20 subjects will be enrolled in the Control Gel treatment arm and approximately 28 subjects in the IDP-126 Gel treatment arm will be enrolled

primary_outcome.measure: Incidence of Treatment-Emergent Adverse Events [Safety and Tolerability]).
primary_outcome.time_frame: All AEs will be followed from onset of the adverse event through the end of Study Day 28 visit
primary_outcome.description: During the study, subjects will be assessed for the occurrence of new and ongoing AEs. Descriptions of AEs will include the dates of onset and resolution, maximum severity, seriousness, action taken regarding study drug, corrective treatment, outcome, and investigator's assessment of causality. Worsening of disease will not be considered an AE unless it results in discontinuation of the subject from the study or requires medical intervention prohibited by the protocol.
